Question: A male fruit fly is homozygous dominant for gray-body color (G) and is crossed with a female fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for ebony-body color (g). What are the probable phenotypes of the offspring?

Choices:
A: 25% gray, 75% ebony
B: 50% gray, 50% ebony
C: 100% ebony
D: 100% gray
steps: The male fruit fly is homozygous dominant for gray-body color, meaning he has two dominant alleles (GG).
The female fruit fly is homozygous recessive for ebony-body color, meaning she has two recessive alleles (gg).
When these two fruit flies are crossed, their offspring will inherit one allele from each parent. Thus, all offspring will receive a G from the male and a g from the female.
As a result, all the offspring will have the genotype Gg, which means they will express the dominant phenotype, gray-body color.
